div.l: Whilome as olde stories tellen vs
Ther͗e was a Duke that hight Theseus
Of Athenes he was lord and governour
And in his tyme suche a Conquerour
That gretter was ther͗e noon̄ vnd̉er the son
Full many a riche countre had he won
What with his wisdome and his chivalrie
He conquered all the reigne of Femynye
That whilome was I cleped scithia
And wedded the Quene Ipolita
And broght hir̉e home with hym in his countree.
Wᵗith much glorie and gʳte solempinte
And eke hir͗e yonge sustre Emele
And thus with victorie and melodie
Late I this noble Duke to Athenes ride
And all his ofte in armes hym beside
And certes if it nere to long to here
I wold haue told fully the manere
How wonnen was the reigne of Femynye
By Theseus and by his Chivalrye
And of the grete batell for the noones
Betwix Athenes and Amazones
And how asseged was Ipolita
The fair hardie quene of Scithia
And of the fest that was at hir͗e wedding
And of the tempest at hir͗e home cōmmynge
But all that thing I mote as now forbere
I haue gode wote a large felde to ere
And wayke ben͗e the oxen in the plough
The remanᵃnt of the tale is long enough
I wolle nott letten noon eke of this route
Late eu͗ery fellay tell his tale aboute
And late see now whoo shall the souper wyn
And ther͗e I left I wolle agayn begyn
This Duke of whome I make mencyon
Whan he was comen allmost to the town
In all his wele and all his most pride
He was war͗e as he cast his egh a side
Wher͗e that ther͗e kneled in the high wey
A company of ladies be twey and twey
Ech aftre othre clad in clothes blake
Bot suche a cry and suche a woo they make
That in this world is creature lyving
That has herd such an othre weymenting
And of this cry they wold neủer stynten
To they the reynes of his bridell henten
What folk bene ye that in myn home comyng
Perturbe my fest so with crying
Quod Theseus . have ye so grete envye
Of myn honour that thus compleyn and crie
Or whoo has you mysboden or offended
And telleth me if it may be amended
And whi that ye be thus clothed in blak /
The eldest ladie of theim all spak
Whan she had swouned with a dedly chere
That it was routh forto se and here
She said lorde to whome fortune hath yeven
Victorie · and as a conqueroᵘur to lyven
Noght greved vs · your͗e glorie and your͗e honour͗e
Bot we besech mercy and socour͗e
Have mercy on our͗e woo and our͗e distresse
Sum drope of pitee thurgh thy gentilnesse
Vpon vs wreched women lat now fall
For certes lord ther͗e is noon of vs all
That she hath bene a Duchesse or a quene
Now be we caitefs as it is wele I seen
Thanked be fortune and hir͗e fals whele
That noon estate eusureth forto be wele
Now certes lorde forto abide youre p̉resence
Here in this temple of the goddes clemence
We have ben͗e wayting all this fourtinight
Help vs lord sith it is in thy might
I wrecche which that wepe and wayle thus
Was whilome the wyfe of the king Campaneus
That starf at Thebes cursed be that day
And all we that ben͗e in this array
And maken all this lamentacion
We losten all our͗e husbondes at that town
While the sege ther aboute lay
And yitt nowe the olde Creon weiloway
That lord is nowe of Thebes the Citee
Fullfilled of ne and of iniquitee
He for despite and for his tirannye
To doon the bodies vilany
Of all oure lordes which that ben͗e slawe
Hath all the bodies on an hepe I drawe
And woll not suffre them by oon assent
Neither to bene I buried neithir͗e I brent
Bot maketh houndes ete them in despite
And with that word withouten more respite
They fellen on grief and cried pitouslye
Haue on vs wreched women Sūm Sūm mercy
And lete ou͗e sorowe sink in thin hert
This gentle Duke down from his coursoᵘur stert
With hert pitous whan he herd theim speke
Him thoght that his hert wold breke
Whan he saw theim so pitous and so mate
That whilome wer͗e of so grete astate
And in his armes he them all vp hent
And them comforteth in full goode entent
And swore his othe as he was true knight
He wold doo so ferfurthly his might
Vpon that Tiraunt Creon them to wreke
That all the people of Grece shall doo speke
How Creon was of Theseus I served
As he that had his dethe full wele deserved
And right anoon withouten any more abode
His banner he displayed and furth he rode
To Thebes ward and all his menye him beside
No ner͗e Athenes · wold he goo ne ride
Ne take his ease fully half a day
Bot onward on his way that night he lay
And sent anoon Ipolita the Quene
And Emelie hir͗e yong sustere sheene
Vnto the town of Athenes to dwell
And furth he rides ther͗e nys nomore to tell
The reid statue of Mars with sper͗e and targe
So shyneth in his white banner large
That all the felde glittered vp and downe
And by his banner born was his pēnowne
Of gold full riche in which ther was I bete
The Minotaure the which he wan in Crete
Thus rides this Duke this conquerour
And in his ooste of / chivalrie the flour
Till that come to Thebes and a light
Fair in a felde ther͗e as he thoght to fight
Bot shortlie forto speken of this thing
With Creon which was of Thebes king
He faght and slogh him manlie as a knight
In playn batell and put his folk to flight
And be assaute he wan the Citee aftre
And rent adown both spar͗e and wall and raft̉er
And to the ladies he restored agayn
The boones of their Frendes that wer sleyn
To doon obsequies as was tho the guyse
Bot it wer͗e all to long for to devise
The grete clamoᵘur and Waymenting /
That the ladies made at the burying
Of the bodies and the grete honour
That Theseus the noble Conqueroᵘur
Dothe to the ladies whan they from him went
Bot shortlie to tell is myn entent
Whan that this Worthie Duke this Theseus
Hath Creon slayn and wonn Thebes thus
Still in that felde he toke all night his rest
And did with all the countree as him list
To ransake in the chase of the bodies deid
Theim forto stripe of harnes and wede
The piloures diden besines and cure
Aftir the batell and the disconifiture
And so befell that in the chase they founde
Thurgh sinyten with grevous blodie wounde
Twoo young knightes lygyng by and by
Bothe in armes same wroght full richely
Of which twoo Arcite hight that oon
And that othir͗e hight Palamon
Noght fully quike ne fully deid they were
Bot by their͗e cote armures and by their͗e gere
The heraudes knewe theym two in speciall
As thoo that were͗e of the bloode riall
Of Thebes and sisteren twoo I born
Oute of the chase the piloures hane theim torn
And have theim caried soft vnto the tent
Of Theseus and he full sone has sent
To Athenes to dwellen in prison
Perpetually for he wold noght theim rawnson
And whan this worthie Duke had thus doon
He toke his oste and home he rideth anoon
With crowne crowned as a conqueroᵘʳ
And ther͗e he lyveth in ioye and honoᵘʳ
Terme of his lyfe what nedes wordes moo
And in a towre in anguysh and in dooo
Dwellen this Palamoıı̄un and eke Arcite
For eủermore ther͗e may noo gold theim quite
This passeth yeer̉e be yeer̉e and day be day
Till it fill oons in a mornyng of May
That Emelie that fairer was to seen
Than is the lillie vpon his stalk green
And fressher̉e than the May with flovres newe
For with the rose coloure strofe hir̉e hewe
I not. which was fairer of theim twoo
Er it wer̉e day as was hir̉e wonn to doo
She was arisen and all redie dight
For May wold haue no sloggard on night
That season prikketh eủery gentle hertt
And maketh it oute of his slepe to stertt
And sithen arise and doo may observance
This maketh Emelie to haue Remembrance
To doon honoᵘʳ to May and forto arise
Clothed was she fressh to devise
Hir͗e yalowe here was braded in a tresse
By hynd hir͗e bak. a yerde long I gesse
And in the gardyn at the son vp rist
She walked vp and down as hir͗e list
She gadred floures partie white and reid
To make a Sutell garland for hir͗e herd
And as an Aungell hevenlie she song
The grete toure that was so thikk and strong
The which of the Castell was the chief dongeon
Ther͗e as the knightes wer͗e in prison
Of which I told you and tell shall
Was even ionand to the gardyn wall
Ther͗e as Emelie had hir͗e playng
Bright was that son and clere in the mornyng
And Palamon this woofull prisoner
As was his won by the leyve of his aler
Was risen and rom̄med in a chaumbre on highe
In the which he all the noble Citee sighe
And eke the gardyn full of braunches green
Ther͗e as the fressh Emelie the sheen
Was in hir͗e walk and rōmmed vp and down
This soryfull Prisoner this Palamon
Goth in the chambre rōmmyng to and fro
And to him self compleyned of his wo
That he was born full oft said allas
And so it befell by aventure or case
That thurgh a Wyndowe of many a barre
Of irne grete and thikk as any sparre
He cast his eghen vpon Emelia
And therwithall he bleinte and cried A A
As thogh he smyten wer͗e vnto the hert
And with that cry Arcite anoon vp stert
And said cosyn myn what ayleth the
That art so pale · and so deidly on to see
Why cridest thou · whoo hast the doon offence
For goddes lufe take all in pacience
Oure prison for it may noo bettir bee
Fortune has yeven vs this aduersitee
Sum wikked aspect or disposicion
Of Saturn by sum Constellacion
Hath yeven vs this all thogh we had it sworn
So stoode the heven when we wer͗e born
We mote endure it . this is short and pleyn
This Palamon answerd and said ageyn
Cosyn for sothe of this opinion
Thou hast a vayn Imagynacion
This prison causeth me not to crye
Bot I was hurt right now thurgh my nye
Into myn hert that wolle my bane be
The fairnes of that ladie that I see
Yonde in the gardyn rōmmen to and fro
Is cause of all my criyng and woo
I not wher͗e she be woman or goddes
But Venus is it as I sothly gesse
And therwithall down on knees he fell
And said Venus if it be thy will
Thus in this gardyn the to transfigure
Before me sorofull wreched creature
Outt of this prison help that we may skape
And if so be my destynyt be shape
By eterne word to dien in prison
Of our͗e Image haue sum compassion
That is so low I broght by tirannye
And with that word Arcite gan espye
Wher͗e as this ladie rōmmed to and fro
And with that sight hir͗e beautie hurt him so
That if that Palamoıı̄un was wounded sore
Arcite is hurt as much as he or elles more
And with a sigh he said pitouslye
The fressh beautie sleeth me sodanlye
Of hir͗e that rometh in the yondir place
And bot I haue hir͗e mercy and hir͗e grace
That I may seen hir͗e at the lest way
I ne am bot deid ther͗e is no more to say
This Palamon when he thes wordes herd
Despitously he loked · and answerd
Whethir sais thou this in ernyst or in pley
Nay quod Arcite in ernyst by my fey
God helpe me so · me list full will pley
This Palamon gan knyt his browes twey
Itt wer͗e to the noo grete honour
Forto be fals ne forto be traitour
To me that am thyn Cosyn and thy brothre
I sworn full depe · and ich of vs to othre
That neủer forto die in noo peyn
Till that dethe · depart shal vs tweyn
Neithre in lufe to hyndir othre
Ne in noon othre case my dere brothre
But that thou shuldest truly forthermore
In eủery case · and I shall forther̉e the there
This was thine othe · and my also certeyn
I wote right wele thou may it not with sayn
Thus art thou of my counsell oute of doute
And now thou woldest falslie bene aboue
To luf my ladie whome I lufe and serve
And eủer shall till that myn hert sterve
Now certes fals Arcite thou shalt not so
I lufed hir̉e first and told the my woo
As to my counsaill and to my brothre sworn
To forthre me as I haue told beforn
For which thou art I bounden as a knight
To helpe me if it lay in thy might
Or elles art thou fals I dar wele sayn
This Arcite full proudely spake agayn
Thou shalt quod he · rather befals than I
And thou art fals I tell the wittirly
For ꝑparamoᵘur I luffed hir͗e first or thou
What wilt thou sayn · thou wist it ȝit not now
Whethre she be a woman or goddesse
Thin is affeccion holynesse
And myn is lufe as to a creature
For which I told the mȳn adventure
As to my brothre crewly sworne
I pose thou lovedest hir͗e beforne
Wost thou not wele the old clerkes sawe
That who shal yeve a lover͗e any lawe
Luf is a grettir law be my pan
Than may be yeve till any eithlie man
And therfore positive law in suche decree
Is broken all day · for luf in ich degree
A man mote nedes luf maugre his heid
He may not fleen it thogh he shuld be deid
All be she mayde or wydow or elles wyfe
And eke it is not liklie all thy life
To stonden in hir͗e grace nomore shal I
For wele thou wotest thy self veraly
That thou and I be dampned to prison
Perpetually · vs gayneth no ravnson
We striven as houndes for the boon
They foghten all day and yit ther͗e parte was noon
Ther͗e come a kyte while they wer͗e wrothe
That bare a way the boone betwen them bothe
And therfore at the kynges courte my brothre
Eche man ther͗e is noon othre
Luse if the list for I lufe and ay shall
And shortlie dere brothre this is all
Litre in this prison mote we endure
And eủerych of vs take his aventure
Grete was the strife and long betwix theim twoo
If that I had leiser for to seye
Bot to this effect it happed vpon a day
To tellen it you as shortlie as I may
A worthie Duke that hight Potheus
That fellaw was vnto Duke Theseus
Sithen that ilk day that they were childre lite
Was comen to Athenes his fellaw to visite
And forto pley as he was won to doo
For in this world he lufed noo man soo
And he lufed him also tendirly agayn
So wele they lufed as olde bokes sayn
That whan that oon was died for sothe to tell
His fellaw went and soght him down in hell
Bot of that storie list me not to write
Duke Perotheus lufed wele Arcite
And had him knowe at Thebes yere by yere
And finally at the Request and preyer̉e
Of Perotheus withouten any Raunson
Duke Theseus him lete onto of prisoıı̄un
Frely to goon wher̉e that him list oủerall
In suche a wyfe as I you tell shall
This was the forward pleynly to endite
By twix Theseus and him Arcite
That if so were . that Arcite wer̉e found
Eủer in his life by day or night or stound
In any countree of this Theseus
And he wer̉e take it was accorded thus
That with a swerd he shuld lese his heid
Ther̉e is noon othre remedie ne reid
He take his leve and homeward he him sped
Lat him be warr̉e his nekke lith to wed
How grete a sorow suffreth nowe Arcite
The dethe he feleth thurgh his hert Smyte
He wepeth weileth crieth pitouslie
To sleyen him selve he weiteth privelie
He said allas the day that I was borne
Now is my prison wars than was beforne
Now is me shape eternally to dwell
Noght in purgatorie but in hell
Allas that eủer I kend Perotheus
For elles had I dwelled with Theseus
I fettered in his prisoıı̄un euermoo
Than had I ben͗e in Blis and not in woo
Oonlye the sight of hir͗e whome I serve
Thogh that I neủer hir͗e grace may deserve
Wold haue I suffised right enogh for me
A A dere cosyn Palamoıı̄un quod he
Thyn is the victorie I this aventure
Full blisfully in prisoıı̄un may thou endure
In prisoıı̄un certes nay bot paradise
Wele hath fortune I torned the · the dise
That has the sight of hir͗e and I the absence
For possible is sith thou hast hir͗e presence
And is a knight worthie and able
That by sum case sith fortune is chaungeable
Thou sum tyme mayst. to thi desire atteyn
Bot I that am exiled and barreyn
Of all grace and in so grete dispeir
That ther͗e nys· erthe watir · fier ne heir
Ne creature · that of theim maked is
That may me helpe · or doon comfort in this
Wele oght I sterve · in Wanhope and distres
Fair͗e wele my life my lust and my gladnes
Allas why pleynen men so in comune
Of purveaunce of god or of fortune
That yeves full oft in many a gyse
Wele bettir than they caun theim selve devise
Sum man desiren to haue richer
That causeth oft his murdir or grete sekenes
And sum man wold oute of his prison fayn
That in hous is oft · his meyne slayn
Infinit harmes bene in this matere
We wote not what thing that we prayen here
We fair͗e as he that dronken is as a mous
A dronken man wote wele he has an hous
Bot he not which the right way is thedir
And to a droken man the way is slydir
And certes in this world so faren was
We seken fast aftir Felicite
Bot we goon wrong full oft truly
Thus may we sayn all . and namelich I
That wened and had a grete opinion
That if I might skapen fro prison
Than had I ben̄e in ioye and ꝑparfite hele
Wher͗e nowe I am exiled from my wele
Sith that I may not see you Emelie
I am bot deid ther͗e nys noon othre remedie
Vpon that othir͗e side. Palamoıı̄un
Whan that he wist / that Arcite was agoon̄
Such sorow hemaketh / that the grete tour
Resoneth / of his yelling and his clamoure
The pure fettres: of his leggys grete
Wer͗e of his bittre salt terys weete
Allas qduod he / Arcita Cosyn̄ myn̄e
Of all our͗e stryfe god wot the fruite is thyne
Thou walkest now in Thebes at thyn̄ large
And of woo thou yevest litle charge
Yitt mayst thou / sith thou hast wisdom and manhede
Assemble all the folk of our͗e kinred
And make a werre so sharp to this Citee
That by sum aventure or sum tretee
Thou mayst have hir͗e to ladie and wyfe
For whome me must nedes lose my lyfe
For as by way of possibilitee
Such thou art at thy large of prison̄ free
And art a lord grete is thyn̄ avuᵃntage
More than is myn̄ that sterve her͗e in cage
For I mote wepe and wayle while that I life
With all the woo / that prison̄ may me gyfe
And eke with payne / that luf me gyves also
That doubles all my turment and my woo
Ther͗e with the fier͗e of Ielousie vpstert
Within his brest and hent him by the hert
So woodlie / that he like was to behold
The box tree / or asshen deid and cold
Than said he / AA cruell goddes that governe
This world with bynding of your͗e lufe eterne
And writen in your͗e table of Athamaunt
Youre ꝑparliament and your͗e eterne graunt
What is mankynd more vnto you hold
Than is the shepe / that ligeth in the fold
For slayn is man right as an othir͗e beste
And dwelleth eke in prison̄ and in arrest
And hath sekenes / and grete adủersitee
And of tymes gyltles par dee
What governaunce is in this p̉rescience
That gyltles / turmentz Innocence
And encresseth thus all my peunaunce
That man is bonden̄ to his observaunce
For goddꝭes sake doo lettyn̄ of his will
Ther͗e as a beste may all his luf fullfill
And whan abeste is deid / he hath no peyne
Bot aftir his deth man mot wepe and pleyne
Thogh in this world he have care and woo
Withouten̄ doute it may stonden̄ soo
The answer͗e of this / I let to the dyvynyes
And wele I wote that in this world grete pyn is
Allas I see a serpent or a theefe /
That many a true man̄ hath doon̄ myschefe
Goon̄ at his large / and wher͗e him list may turn̄
Bot I mot ben͗e in prisoıı̄un / thurgh Saturn̄
And eke thurgh mars marred and eke woode
They haue distroyed all the bloode
Of Thebes / which hath wayst walles wyde
And Venus slieth me on͗e that othir͗e syde
For Ielousie / and feer of him Arcite
Now wolle I stynt of Palamoıı̄un a lite
And lett him in his prisoıı̄un still dwell
And of Arcita / furth wolle I you tell
The Somer passeth and the nightes long/
Encreseth double wyse the paynes strong/
Both of the lufer and of the prisoner͗e
I not which haue the wofuller myster͗e
For shorlie forto say of this Palamoıı̄un
ꝐPerpetully is dampned to prisoıı̄un
In cheyns and fettrs to the deid
And Arcite is exiled vpon his heid
For eủermore / as oute of that contree
Ne neủer he shall his ladie see
You luffers now ax I this questioıı̄un
Whoo hath the wers / Arcite or Palamoıı̄un
That oon may see his ladie day by day
Bot in prisoıı̄un he dwelles all way
That othir͗e wher͗e him list may ride or goo
Bot seen his ladie shall he neủer moo
Now dininyth as you list that ye can̄
For I will tell furth as I began̄
Whan that Arcite to Thebes comen̄ was
Full oft tymes of the day he swelt and said allas
For seen̄ his ladie shall he neủer moo
And shortlie to concluden̄ all his woo
So mych sorowe had noo creature
That is or shall / while the world may endure
His slepe his mete is drynk is him byraft
